To: Steve Flook <steve.flook@ihire.com>
Subject: distributions

 

Hi Steve,

 

Thanks for your help on this. Here is what Mel and I are looking at for 2022:

 

May 2022 - received check for $34,535. Memo indicates it is for Q1 distribution and 2022 true up. By my calculations from what the Board voted to distribute and my ownership, roughly $13,500 should be Q1 distribution and $21,000 true up

 

August 2022 - received check for $17,504. Memo indicates it is for Q2 distribution and 2021 equalization. By my calculations almost all of this should be distribution.

 

So our total distribution from those two checks is roughly $31K. Adding the roughly $70K that is coming now that brings our total for 2022 to $101k in distributions. But the K1 says we had $138K in distributions on allocated earnings of $265K in earnings. This also doesn't make sense to me since we were supposed to be distributing 42.5% which for me should have been around  $112,625.

 

Thanks again, and I hope you had a nice Easter weekend.

Megan

from:	Morgan Budzynski <mmbudzyn@ncsu.edu>

date:	May 20, 2024, 12:48 PM
subject:	UHP Upper-Level Event: Williamsburg, VA - Colonial and Water Country USA

Hi Wolfpack,

I'm pleased to introduce the second Upper-Level Event of the summer -- the University Honors Program is heading back up to Virginia for a weekend in Williamsburg!

Screenshot 2024-05-19 at 1.27.52 PM.png

We'll have a Friday morning departure on June 7th and spend the afternoon exploring Colonial Williamsburg; we'll tour the Governor's Palace, Capitol, and Raleigh Tavern, and we'll visit trade shops, historic houses, and exhibition sites of Williamsburg's 18th century residents. Then we'll check into The Historic Powhatan, a residences resort with amenities including: indoor and outdoor pools, a sauna, tennis and racquetball courts, and a mini-golf course.

Saturday will be devoted to Water Country USA, Virginia's largest water park -- wave pools, lazy rivers, water coasters, live entertainment, and more! We'll call it quits when the park closes at 7pm and return to The Historic Powhatan for one more night before our departure on Sunday morning. 

Including transportation, two nights at The Historic Powhatan, a half day at Colonial Williamsburg, and a full day at Water Country USA, this trip is available to UHP students at the low cost of $95. If this trip sounds like something you absolutely must add to your summer, please fill out this google form.

Thank you and have a great week!

--
Morgan Budzynski (she/her)
North Carolina State University
M.A. in Rhetoric and Composition C/O 2025
Administrative Assistant, University Honors Program

from:	University Honors <universityhonors@ncsu.edu>
sent by:	melobsin@ncsu.edu
reply-to:	melobsin@ncsu.edu
to:	
bcc:	group-scholars-students-all@ncsu.edu
date:	Apr 29, 2024, 1:23 PM
subject:	UHP Requirements Explained: High Impact Experiences

UHP Requirements Explained: High Impact Experiences
University Honors students (admitted for the Fall of 2022 or later) and University Scholars students complete a total of three high impact experiences (HIEs) by the time they graduate. These are opportunities for students to engage in experiential learning outside the classroom in a way that directly aligns with their individual goals. This requirement also gives students the opportunity to reflect on how these experiences impact their learning in preparation for life after college such as graduate school or employment applications.

This email is meant to serve as a gentle reminder that if you completed what would qualify as a High Impact Experience at any point during this academic school year, it is preferred you submit your reflection essay for that HIE before we get very far into the summer months. DO NOT stress over writing these reflections before your final exams are over, but please do submit them sometime soon after! Ideally, going forward, we would like students to submit their reflections within the same semester that their HIE concluded (within 4-6 weeks) so that the experience is still fresh in their minds and they have plenty of details to share in their reflection essay.

DISCIPLINARY BREADTH EXCEPTION: the exception to the above “deadline guideline” of “within 4-6 weeks of the experience concluding” is our “Disciplinary Breadth” category. If a student is double majoring or majoring and minoring in academic programs from two different academic colleges, we would rather you wait until the semester of your graduation to reflect on what studying under those differing academic programs has done for you as a person and future professional. 

An explanation of the High Impact Experience requirement has always been linked on our website, but we have also recently recorded a short (4:19) video, linked below with a transcript, to better explain the HIE requirement and the various HIE categories under which students can submit their HIE reflections.

Since this video was recorded, an additional slide has been added to the HIEs Explained slide deck with some examples of professional and/or personally developmental opportunities available to students from around the University that would definitely qualify as a High Impact Experience upon successful completion.

HONORS CAPSTONE PROJECT : Remember that students who submit their undergraduate research as an Honors Capstone Project can earn two out of their three required High Impact Experiences at once!

If you have any questions or concerns about the High Impact Experience requirement for the Honors Program, please reach out to your Honors Program advisor.

To submit a High Impact Experience reflection essay, please use this Google Form.

from:	Chloe Coursey <cpcours2@ncsu.edu>
to:	Mehmet Ozturk <mco@ncsu.edu>
date:	Feb 20, 2024, 3:49 PM
subject:	IMPORTANT ECE 403 001 Exam Tomorrow

Good Afternoon,

You do not know me because I am not in one of your classes but I’m reaching out to you on behalf of one of your current students Owen Gabriel Gromyko.

I’m honestly not sure if he is in your class but i know he is in ECE 401 001 and is expecting to take an exam tomorrow at 8:30. If he is not one of your students, I apologize and hope you can redirect me accordingly.

I’m sure this is unusual, but I want to ask if it would even be possible for him to take his exam at least later in the day. He is sick with what I believe is the flu. I’ve been tending to him for a bit and he is having HORRIBLE muscle fatigue, sweats, pains, etc. All classic signs of the flu. I came over after he took an exam this morning and he told me how bad he was doing and that he had no pain meds for his headache. As his partner I came to help him. I’ve been on his bedside changing a cool cloth every few minutes because his temperature keeps causing it to heat up so quickly. Unfortunately he doesn’t have a thermometer where he lives so I can’t even send formal proof of his state. 

I told him to try and reach out earlier but he assured me there was no way his exam could be considered for a later time. However, considering the increased emphasis on student health physically and mentally, I was hoping you would consider, if nothing else, allowing him to take the exam at a different hour. As I’m sure you can conclude, being this sick and worrying about an 8:30 am exam is not ideal for the healing process.

I do apologize for any inconvenience this may cause or disrespect this may come across as on my part, but I want what is best for him and I’m confident an exam tomorrow is not that, much less at 8:30 in the morning.

I did not copy him on this email because I did not want his hopes to get up; plus I know him and he’d probably try to tough it out instead of risking offending a professor. I hope you will consider what I am suggesting.

Best,
Chloe Coursey

email_text:
From:   Derek Kramper <dgkamper@ncsu.edu>
Date: Mon, Nov 13, 2023 at 9:41 PM
Subject: RE:BME385 : Inquiry Regarding Results Section and RMSE Calculation
To: Cindy Nguyen <tqnguye6@ncsu.edu>
Hi Cyndy,

You should include all of the data in your table (3 separate measurements for each force). RMSE refers to the fit of the model - 
what is the difference between your data points and the value predicted by the line or the quadratic curve predicted by the model
(RMSE for the fit of each model).


Best,
Derek Kamper, Ph.D.

Associate Director, Closed Loop Engineering for Advanced Rehabilitation (CLEAR)

University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill

email_text:
From: Cindy Nguyen <tqnguye6@ncsu.edu>
Sent: Tuesday, April 23, 2024 2:48 AM
To: bob bobslab.com <bob@bobslab.com>
Cc: bob@unc.edu <bob@unc.edu>; Cindy Nguyen <tqnguye6@ncsu.edu>
Subject: BME 375 Final Exam - Cindy Nguyen
Hi Bob,

Please see below for my answers to the final exam questions. I want to take this opportunity to thank you for your guidance and support throughout the course. Your insights have been invaluable to my learning experience. Thank you once again.

*************************************

Microcontrollers I - Spring 2024

FINAL EXAMINATION


Q1: Describe in 1 or 2 sentences what each of these Arduino functions or operators do:



random(min, max): Generates pseudo-random numbers. It returns a random number between min and max-1.





delay(): Pauses the program for the amount of time (in milliseconds) specified as a parameter. It is useful for creating
 longer delays where timing precision is not critical.





delayMicroseconds(): This function pauses the program for the specified number of microseconds. It is useful for creating
 very short delays, especially when working with timing-sensitive components (i.e. sensors or communication protocols).





micros(): Returns the number of microseconds since the Arduino board began running the current program.





millis():  Returns the number of milliseconds since the Arduino board began running the current program





analogWrite(): generates a PWM signal on a specified pin, allowing control over the output voltage level, which is
 useful for controlling the brightness of an LED, the speed of a motor, or the position of a servo.





!=  (example: x != y): stands for "not equal to" and is used to compare two values. The expression x != y evaluates
 to ‘true’ if x is not equal to y, and ‘false’ otherwise.





%:
Calculates the remainder when one integer is divided by another.





&&: It is the logical AND operator used to combine two conditions. It returns true if both conditions it connects
 are true, and false





==: Compares the left variable with the right value or variable in the operator, returning ‘true’ if they are equal.





=: 
It is the assignment operator used to assign a value to a variable





EEPROM.put():
Writes values to the EEPROM using variable semantics.





EEPROM.get():
Retrieves values from EEPROM so that we can print them as floats on the serial monitor using Serial.print()
or Serial.println() 



Q2: For the millis() function, how long will the counter run before it overflows (reaches its maximum then starts counting again from zero)?



The counter is an ‘unsigned long’ type, which means it can hold values from
0 to 4,294,967,295 (2^32 - 1). This number will overflow (go back to zero), after approximately
50 days.



Q3: For the micros() function, how long will the counter run before it overflows (reaches its maximum then starts counting again from zero)?



The counter is an ‘unsigned long’ type, which means it can hold values from 0 to 4,294,967,295 (2^32 - 1). This number will overflow (go back to zero), after approximately
71.6 minutes.



Q4: For the analogWrite() function, using your Arduino Uno, what are the PWM frequencies that you would get on the analog output pins?



The Arduino Uno's analogWrite() function uses PWM on pins 3, 5, 6, 9, 10, and 11. The PWM frequency on most pins is around
490 Hz, while pins 5 and 6 have a frequency of around
980 Hz. 



Q5: On the Arduino Uno, several data types are available.  For the data type "int":

 - How many bytes are stored in an "int"?



There are 2 bytes in an “int”.


 - What are the minimum and maximum values that can be stored in an int?



The minimum value that can be stored is -32,768,
 and the maximum value is 32,767 in an int.



Q6: On the Arduino Uno, several data types are available.  For the data type "float":

 - How many bytes are stored in a "float"? 



There are 4 bytes in a “float”.


 - What are the minimum and maximum values that can be stored in a float?



“float” data type can represent a wide range of values. The minimum value that can be stored in a float is -3.4028235E+38 and
 the maximum value is 3.4028235E+38.



Q7: On the Arduino Uno, several data types are available.  For the data type "unsigned int":

 - How many bytes are stored in an "unsigned int"?



There are 2 bytes in an “unsigned int”.


 - What are the minimum and maximum values that can be stored in an unsigned int?



The minimum value that can be stored in an unsigned int is
0, and the maximum value is
65,535.



Q8: On the Arduino Uno, several data types are available.  For the data type "long":

 - How many bytes are stored in a "long"?



There are 4 bytes in “long”.


 - What are the minimum and maximum values that can be stored in a long?



The minimum value that can be stored in a long is
-2,147,483,648, and the maximum value is
2,147,483,647.



Q9: Many Arduino circuits are built using a solderless breadboard. These can cause problems. Describe at least one major problem that can be caused by using a solderless breadboard?



Solderless breadboards can cause problems with complex circuits because of the large amount of wiring required. A major issue with solderless breadboards is their less secure connections compared to
 soldered ones, which can lead to unreliable circuit behavior especially with high-frequency or high-current circuits.



Q10:

What is an "internal pullup"?



An "internal pullup" is a resistor that can be internally connected to a digital input pin in an Arduino. It pulls the pin's voltage to HIGH (5V) when the pin is not actively driven LOW (0V), helping
 maintain a defined voltage level on the pin in the absence of an external circuit. This prevents floating inputs and reduces electrical noise.



How do you use it (how do you activate it)?



To activate the internal pullup resistor, you use the
pinMode()
function with the mode INPUT_PULLUP. For example,
pinMode(pin, INPUT_PULLUP);



What command is used by Arduino to activate an internal pullup?



pinMode(pin, INPUT_PULLUP);



What does it do?



The INPUT_PULLUP mode in Arduino sets a digital pin to the HIGH level by connecting an internal resistor between the digital pin and the power supply (VCC). This pull-up resistor typically has a value
 of around 20-50 kΩ and helps prevent floating inputs, which can lead to high current consumption.



Why would you use it?



An internal pullup is used to simplify circuit design by removing the necessity for an external resistor to pull a digital input pin to the HIGH level. This is particularly useful when connecting switches
 or buttons that are normally open, as the internal pullup resistor ensures a stable HIGH state when the switch or button is not pressed.



Q11: To find answers to questions you may have in the future, for further learning, or to see new project Ideas, list at least three resources that are freely available to you:



Arduino Forum: The forum is helpful for seeking answers to Arduino-related questions and discovering fresh project
 ideas.




ChatGPT:
It's a useful tool for debugging code and getting answers to various questions, although its accuracy may vary.




Classmates:
Other students in the class could offer insights and solutions to common problems, making them a great resource for addressing questions.




Youtube: It’s a rich source of tutorials and project demonstrations for Arduino enthusiasts.



Q12: Think of a medical or health-related device that you could build using a microcontroller such as an Arduino. Describe the device, what it is useful for, and how it would work, with a brief discussion of the features you would use to make the device function.



A medical device that I could build using a microcontroller such as an Arduino is the
Finger Pulse Oximeter.
It is used to measure blood oxygen saturation (SpO2) and heart rate. The device uses LEDs to emit light through a finger, which is then measured by a photodetector to determine the SpO2 and calculate
 the heart rate. The microcontroller controls the LEDs, reads the photodetector signal, processes the data to calculate SpO2 and heart rate, and displays the results on a screen.





Features:




LEDs: Emit light at specific wavelengths (usually red) to penetrate the skin and blood.




Photodetector: Detect the light transmitted through the finger and convert it into an electrical signal.




Signal Processing: Algorithms to process the photodetector signal and calculate SpO2 and heart rate.





From: Cindy Nguyen <tqnguye6@ncsu.edu>
Sent: Tuesday, April 23, 2024 2:48 AM
To: bob bobslab.com <bob@bobslab.com>
Cc: bob@unc.edu <bob@unc.edu>; Cindy Nguyen <tqnguye6@ncsu.edu>
Subject: BME 375 Final Exam - Cindy Nguyen 
Display: Show the measured SpO2 and heart rate values.




User Interface: Buttons or a touchscreen to control the device and navigate menus.




Power Supply: Battery or external power source to power the device.



Note: Alternatively, an oximeter sensor such as the MAX30101 by SparkFun can be used in replacement of the LEDs and the photodetector. The MAX30101 performs sensing by using its internal LEDs to bounce light off the arteries and arterioles in the finger's subcutaneous layer, while its photodetectors sense how much light is absorbed. 

*************************************

Sincerely,
Cindy N.

Hi Dr. Chandler,

I hope you're doing well! I was looking for some help and clarification on the paper. I'm writing about the history and impact of the One-Child Policy:

1) If I write multiple sentences in a row using information from the same source, should each 
sentence have a separate footnote? How about if they are taken from the same or different page from the source?
 


2) I wanted to run my updated argument by you: "The widespread social and economic repercussions of the One-Child Policy are unlikely to be addressed by the Three-Child Policy." Should I go further into reasons why in my thesis? I would mention the massive portion of the population leaving the workforce, the skill/sex composition of the workforce, urban/rural child-raising costs for economic impacts. For social impacts, I want to talk about the impacts of more men in society, such as more discontent and fertility rate decline. These impacts will last for decades, and incentives the Three-Child Policy won't boost fertility in the short-term as child-raising costs are still very high and many developed countries have low fertility rates. 

 
3) Is there a minimum word count? The footnotes look like they will take up a decent portion of the page.


 
Thanks for your help!

Best,
Melissa

email_text:
From: Katerina Ramos, Red Wolf Education & Outreach Coordinator, NCWF <katerina@ncwf.org>
Date: Fri, May 17, 2024 at 8:30 AM
Subject: Step Up for Red Wolves
To: <tlbelus@ncsu.edu>
 
Good morning Trisha,



Today is Endangered Species Day and you have an opportunity to protect, conserve, and restore Red Wolves in the wild in North Carolina. As one of the most endangered canids in the world, only found in the wild in North Carolina, what could be a greater purpose on this Endangered Species Day?



To get inspired, watch my brief video below to learn about Red Wolves and why Endangered Species Day is so important.

Endangered Species Day message from NCWF Red Wolf Education & Outreach Coordinator
With 17 known Red Wolves in the wild, they are threatened daily by roads and vehicles running throughout their habitat as well as by gunshot. NCWF is committed to addressing these risks.



When you drive on U.S. Highway 64 towards Alligator River National Wildlife Refuge, you will likely see electronic signage telling you to slow down because you're in Red Wolf territory. NCWF helped pay for these signs and is advocating for more fencing and wildlife crossings to prevent Red Wolf and other wildlife vehicle collisions.



You may also see signs on private property that read "Prey for the Pack". NCWF works with U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service and private landowners on the Albemarle Peninsula to expand Red Wolf habitat by making habitat improvements that benefit Red Wolves, other wildlife, and the landowner through this cost-share program.



I work every day to raise awareness about Red Wolves by operating the Red Wolf Center in Columbia, North Carolina. However, my favorite way to share the Red Wolf story is taking people out on the Alligator River and Pocosin Lakes National Wildlife Refuges to experience Red Wolf habitat and all the wildlife that live there.



Come visit me at the Red Wolf Center and in the meantime, I invite you to donate to NCWF's Endangered Species May campaign to raise $10,000 by the end of May for Red Wolves, other listed wildlife, and those of greatest conservation need in North Carolina.



We are lucky here in North Carolina, to be home to the world's only wild Red Wolves. Let's not let them go extinct on our watch!



Thank you for caring and I hope to see you at the Red Wolf Center soon!



Gratefully,

Kat

Donate
	
Katerina Ramos

Columbia, NC 27925

email_text:
From: Tim Gestwicki, CEO, NCWF <tim@ncwf.org>
Date: Thu, May 16, 2024 at 8:31 AM
Subject: Remembering Extinct Wildlife in NC
To: <tlbelus@ncsu.edu>
Trisha,



I often get questions about the prominent bison in NCWF's logo. It was introduced in 1969 to commemorate the organization’s 25th anniversary. It symbolizes NCWF's vision and strengths.



The National Bison Legacy Act, passed by Congress in April 2016, made the bison a U.S. symbol of resilience, unity, and healthy landscapes and communities.



Bison, unlike cattle, do not turn their backs to storms and bad weather, but face directly into the rain and winds. Like the bison, NCWF is agile, strong, dedicated to the cause, and faces a challenge full on.



Maybe one day the bison will be reintroduced in the wild in North Carolina too.



Other extinct species that once called North Carolina home, include the Carolina parakeet, passenger pigeon, and Bachman's warbler.



Though these species are some of the few to go fully extinct since colonization, they are not alone in facing threats of extinction, and they are certainly not the only ones to experience significant population declines at the hands of market hunting, habitat loss, and resource scarcity.



Tomorrow is Endangered Species Day and NCWF is raising awareness about endangered, threatened, and species of greatest conservation need in order to prevent further losses. You can make a difference right now by doing two things:



Read more about extinct wildlife in North Carolina
Donate to NCWF's Endangered Species May campaign to raise $10,000 by the end of May to support NCWF's work to protect, conserve, and restore listed species and those of greatest conservation need.


Losing wildlife affects us all. Together, we can make a difference.



Thank you,

Tim

Donate
	
Tim Gestwicki

CEO

North Carolina Wildlife Federation

1346 St. Julien Street

Charlotte, NC 28205

Phone (704) 332-5696 

Web www.ncwf.org Email Tim@ncwf.org

P.S. Consider a recurring automated monthly donation. It is the most efficient and effective way to donate to NCWF and help endangered wildlife in North Carolina on Endangered Species Day and throughout the year.

email_text:
From: SciStarter <info@scistarter.org>
Date: Thu, Apr 25, 2024 at 5:51 PM
Subject: Thanks a MILLION…Acts of Science!
To: <tlbelus@ncsu.edu>


You deserve a pat on the back, Belus!

We did it! ONE MILLION Acts of Science during Citizen Science Month this April! All BEFORE the end of the month!  We are so proud of the entire SciStarter community! Thank you 🙌 for being a part of this adventure and for giving your time and energy to so many of the citizen science projects and events listed on SciStarter. 

If you have participated in any SciStarter Affiliate projects, your participation is already counted and on our Wall of Fame. It's not too late to be included on the Wall of Fame for other projects! Using this simple reporting form, you can report other acts (from non-affiliate projects and events).

There is still an entire weekend of events left and we welcome your participation! Here are four for your consideration:


Stall Catchers and the Girl Scouts Overseas 💚 invite you to join their online team to analyze images and help accelerate research on Alzheimer's disease. If you are a Girl Scout, find and join your team here . If you'd like to support the Girl Scouts' effort, join the SciStarter Team.

Join more than 3,000 other volunteers on Monday, April 29th, to learn about the All of Us Research Program during Genes and Journeys: Bridging Gaps in Medical and Societal Accessibility. The All of Us Research Program invites you to engage in this national health research project. The Network of the National Library of Medicine All of Us Program Center (NAPC) is a major sponsor of Citizen Science Month.

The City Nature Challenge 🏙️ begins Friday, April 26th! Cities all around the world are preparing to share observations of nature this weekend! Find details here.  Get Started: Download iNaturalist and create an iNaturalist account. (Optional) Then add your iNat username to your SciStarter profile in "Info & Settings" so each of your nature observations are counted towards the One Million Acts of Science initiative. You'll only do this once. Then...it's time to start observing wildlife all around you!

Then... Celebrate Citizen Science Month outcomes with us on Tuesday, April 30th during SciStarter LIVE at 2pm ET on Zoom. Register to join us here: SciStarter.org/go/LIVE. We'll highlight contributions, hear from participants (including you, we hope!) and reflect on preliminary outcomes. Complete this survey about your experience as a participant and you’ll be eligible for prizes! 🎁 If you're a facilitator of citizen science events, you can also take this survey to share your experience with us.  

Here’s an easy way to share news of your involvement in Citizen Science Month on social media:

“We did it! #OneMillionActsofScience during #CitizenScienceMonth with @SciStarter and many collaborators! Www.OneMillionActsofScience.org"

Thanks a million....acts of science!

Emma Giles she/her

Manager of Public Outreach and Programs @SciStarter

Unsubscribe

From: Mackin, Madison <madison.mackin@skanska.com>
Date: Fri, May 3, 2024 at 10:16 AM
Subject: Welcome to Skanska!
To: Demario Negron <drnegron@ncsu.edu>
Good morning,

Welcome to the team!  We are so excited for you to join us this summer! I wanted to begin walking you through the onboarding process. I just initiated a background check and drug screening via email. It is important to get this done as soon as possible.

Please see the details below regarding a background check and drug screening. If you have any questions at all, please don't hesitate to reach out.

You should have received an email regarding the following:

Background Check
Drug Screening
You will need to fill out the personal information required for Sterling to complete the background check. The entire process should be completed in no more than 5 days. The first 48 hours should be dedicated to ensuring the background check portion is completed by you. Please send me an email once you have completed the background check portion, as this will prompt us to launch out the drug screening portion of your clearance. This will permit you 72 hours to take the drug screening test. Once you enter your preferred address, this will automatically generate the closest drug screening locations to your home address. Please ensure the address you utilize is the address you physically reside in (even if just currently), so that you can get the nearest location. A chain of custody form will then be given to you to take to the laboratory, along with proper identification.

Please ensure you notify us if the following occurs:

You cannot fill out the background check within the given 48 hours.
You cannot take the exam within the given 72 hours (either for personal reasons or unable to secure an appointment). Timely completion of the drug screening should be ensured, as we do expect a week or two turnaround time frames to have results provided back to us.
If you did not receive this email, please let me know AS SOON AS POSSIBLE.

Please let me know if you have any questions.

Best,

Madison Mackin

HR Administrator

Skanska USA Civil

 

Queens, NY 11370, United States

Mobile

+1 929 919 3444

 

Skanska USA

usa.skanska.com

Connect With Us:

Blog | Facebook | Twitter | LinkedIn | Instagram | YouTube

 

Think twice before you press "print."

This message, including any attachments hereto, may contain privileged or confidential information and is sent solely for the attention and use of the intended addressee(s). If you are not an intended addressee, you may neither use this message nor copy or deliver it to anyone. In such case, you should immediately destroy this message and kindly notify the sender by reply email. Thank you.

 

--
Demario Negron
North Carolina State University
Civil Engineering B.S. 2025

from:	NC State Engineering <pfaendtner@ncsu.edu>
reply-to:	collegeofengineering@ncsu.edu
to:	cpcours2@ncsu.edu
date:	May 17, 2024, 10:03 AM
subject:	End-of-year message from Dean Jim Pfaendtner

Dear COE students,

 

I’m writing to wish you all the very best as you head into summer. I am so proud of each of you for your hard work and great outcomes this year. Congratulations! Whether you just graduated or just finished your first year at NC State, you have earned a well-deserved break and I hope your summer plans include time for some rest and fun.

 

Turning the page on another academic year also gives us all the opportunity for reflection, growth and a look toward the future. My sincere hope is that amidst unexpected challenges and surprises of the last year, you also built new relationships, experienced the value of perseverance, and discovered new strengths you didn’t know you possessed.

 

I also want to share my immense gratitude at the overwhelming kindness and enthusiasm with which you greeted me as your new dean of engineering! Every encounter with students in the College, from sharing pizza with our Engineering Ambassadors to helping graduate students find needed resources for their degree progress, has been an important part of my onboarding to our great University. It is the privilege of a lifetime to serve as your dean. My first year here greatly exceeded my expectations in large part due to your hospitality and welcome. Thank you so much.

 

Finally, I want to share with you that our entire leadership team remains unwavering in our commitment to the support and success of all students who walk through our doors. Each of you brings unique perspective, experience and diversity to our teaching and learning. This enriches out work, makes us stronger, and provides a driving force to continually work to foster an environment where everyone feels valued and included.

 

To those of you who have graduated, know that while you are leaving the College, you remain a part of our COE community for a lifetime. And to those of you returning in the fall, please know that we are working overtime this summer to improve our student experience and strengthen all the programs that support you and ensure your wellbeing and achievement.

 

I wish you the very best, and as always do not hesitate to reach out to me at any time via email, LinkedIn, or Instagram.

 

Warmly,


Dean Jim Pfaendtner

email_text:
from:	Megan Coursey <meganpc@comcast.net>
to:	Victoria Cetrone <VCetrone@olgchs.org>
date:	May 4, 2024, 12:31 PM
Hello Ms. Cetrone,
 
Please do not tell Hayden I sent you this email. He doesn't like us contacting his teachers and we encourage him to be as independent as possible with contacting teachers himself. However, it is still our responsibility to ensure that his anxiety and ADHD are under the best control possible and that he is utilizing all tools available to cope with both conditions. Therefore, I am contacting you to be sure there isn't something he is missing. Unfortunately, his anxiety holds him back from reaching out to teachers in situations where he knows he messed up something big.  
 
We all understand that the responsibility for this situation lies entirely on Hayden, and nothing in this email is intended to imply that any of it is on you. My goal is to figure out what Hayden did or didn't do to create this situation so I can provide him with as many tools as possible to avoid it in the future.
 
The problem is that Hayden had no idea there was going to be a History test yesterday (hence his poor grade). I asked how he was expected to know about the test. He said it was posted in the Google Classroom stream but he keeps forgetting to read that because almost all of the information is redundant. Instead he goes directly to his "to do" list in Google Classroom and accesses his assignments there. We had a long talk about the importance of reading the stream each day even if it seems like a waste of time to him since even one piece of critical information (like your test announcement), makes it worth reading daily.
 
His not reading the stream and going straight to the "to do" list is partly a function of his anxiety. He is very anxious to get his homework started each night and has a major anxiety spike if he has to do anything prior to starting on his work. This  plays a role in him skipping the feed and going straight to the "to do" list. Again - not making excuses for him, I just want you to understand in case you have any helpful ideas. I am hoping that this experience will make him feel the same urgency over missing information in the stream as he has over getting his homework completed. Additionally, we discussed how he could utilize his planner to help remember to check the stream.
 
So my question to you is whether there was any other way Hayden should have known about the test. Did he miss an announcement in class? Was it posted elsewhere that he should have seen? If the answer is simply that he needs to be better about checking the stream then I think we have done all we can on that for the time being.

email_text:
from:	Jamie Larsen <jlarsen@ncsu.edu>
to:	Chloe Coursey <cpcours2@ncsu.edu>
date:	Mar 6, 2024, 9:15 AM
subject:	Re: ACTIVITY 3.5: FORMULATING AN ARGUMENT
Hi Chloe, For Assignment 3A, I am not asking you to make up any background experience. Your ethos will simply be based on the correctness and professionalism of the overall formal proposal.

I am sending the following information each of your team members in response to this online activity:

Be sure to read all of the notes about each section that is required for Assignment 3A – Collaborative Instruction Proposal. The notes for the proposal body include information about writing step-by-step instructions. The following “must have” list should help you get started on writing instructions if you have not already started:

Introduction and informative title – Tell the user in one line, and in more detail what he/she will be accomplishing by using the instructions. Include all materials that are needed, as well as time required.

Step-by-step list – Use numbered lists with each step beginning with a very specific action verb followed by a description of the expected reaction or result, or a common problem that may occur if the action is done incorrectly

Format, fonts, and figures – Use an easy to follow format with varying fonts to give the users cues about what the information provides (e.g., bold for all actions, a different font for cautions, warning, and dangers, etc.). Use visuals with proper labels to illustrate complex steps, or ones that require an important outcome.

Cautions, Warnings, and Danger Notices – Use the legally correct level of warning. A lot of instructions do not meet that standard for what could happen if an action is taken by a user (e.g., Cautions are used if a wrong result can occur; Warnings are used if something can be broken; Dangers are used if physical harm can result.). Also, include appropriate warning notices in the steps where they apply.

Conclusion – Provide information that recaps what the final result should be, as well as information for additional information or support.

Take a moment to look at a quick some notes about Professional and Writing/Instructions, which have some good tips about instruction writing, as well as usability testing - https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Professional_and_Technical_Writing/Instructions

Have a great day.

Jamie

from:	Chloe Coursey <cpcours2@ncsu.edu>
to:	Disability Resource Office Testing <dro-testing@ncsu.edu>
date:	Dec 11, 2023, 11:06 AM
subject:	 CSC 246 Exam
Good Morning,

I wanted to reach out about my 8AM exam this morning that is to be rescheduled for Wednesday. The 2PM option works for me.


Secondly, I'd like to point out the following: 
I understand there is nothing that could really be done, and my exam was likely going to be rescheduled regardless. But I think it was highly inconsiderate how it was handled. I know the office received notice from my professor before 8 AM this morning that my exam was not to be taken today; because when I arrived prior to 8AM, I was informed that my professor did not want me taking it today. As a DISABILITY resource office, I would like to think the office would understand the potential harm to one of their registered students for not informing them ASAP. Even if the office did not know until the first person arrived this morning, an email would have been much better. To give you a sense this is where I stand now:
I am a student with ADHD, I took my meds at 6AM so that they could be in effect by 8AM. This means, they will no longer be working around 6-7 PM this evening. I have an exam today at 3:30, so my priority from getting home this morning to 3:30 will be studying for that exam. When I get home around 4:30 or 5, I will have approximately an hour of study time (as my meds will not be working past 6). I have two exams the next day at 8AM and 2PM, so my focus will be my 8AM exam, leaving me with no prep for my 2PM exam. Then, I get home another day at 5:45, after a day of taking my meds at 6AM and will barely be able to study for my NOW Wednesday exam at 2PM. So now, I have almost 2 days to lose all knowledge for my exam. Of course this is a bit of an exaggeration, and since I have lived with ADHD for almost 21 years, I have mechanisms to try and study after my meds are worn off, but I still am not as productive. 

I know there was not much you could do, but I want to bring attention to how highly inconsiderate it was to not inform me immediately after knowing the situation. And how ESPECIALLY inconsiderate it was to send me my location notice at 5:19 PM if you guys had already known (which I suspect/hope you did not). I do appreciate your time and effort to reschedule my exam. I just wanted to let you know so that maybe if this happens to another/with another student in the future it can be prevented.

From: Terrie Noland, Ph.D. <Spotlightdyslexia@learningally.org>

Subject: [Dyslexia Conference] One week left to get your free ticket!

SPOD24 Email Header Week7.png

Dear Justin,

Spotlight on Dyslexia, Learning Ally’s highly anticipated virtual conference, is just one week away! When we go live on June 5th and 6th, Spotlight on Dyslexia will bring together a community of educators, school leadership, experts, and thought leaders, all dedicated to enhancing your understanding of dyslexia and improving student support and outcomes.

With just one week to go, here's why you don't want to miss out:

Engaging Speakers: This year’s conference features an exceptional lineup, including keynote presentations from Dr. Pamela Snow and Dr. Jason Yeatman.
Professional Learning: You'll gain valuable strategies, resources, and best practices to enhance your ability to support students with dyslexia, as well as the opportunity to earn 35+ hours of CE certificates.
Networking: Expand your professional network and engage in meaningful discussions during our interactive networking sessions.
Inspiration: Join us for a dyslexia simulation; this unique experience will immerse you in the educational journey of students with reading difficulties. It's an opportunity to explore their obstacles in a safe and supportive environment, free from judgment, and alongside peers who share your background and knowledge.
Use discount code SPOD24TRIUMPH to get $20 off a full-access Gold Ticket or register for a FREE limited-access Silver Ticket. Don't miss this unique opportunity to enhance your knowledge and skills!

Sincerely,
TNoland_Signature.png
Terrie Noland, Ph.D., CALP
Vice-President, Educator Initiatives
Learning Ally

Register Today!
About Learning Ally
LEARNING ALLY is a leading nonprofit education solutions organization dedicated to equipping educators with proven solutions that help new and struggling learners reach their potential. Our range of literacy-focused offerings for students Pre-K to 12th grade, including our award-winning reading resource, the Learning Ally Audiobook Solution®, our new early literacy solution, Excite Reading®, and catalog of professional learning allow us to support more than 2.5 million students and over 615,000 educators across the US. For more information, visit LearningAlly.org.

They also (of course) help us understand what can be done better, what you absolutely loved, and what we need more of. Your feedback here is greatly valued.

If you attended any standard Upper-Level Events, please fill out this survey.

If you attended any of the Upper-Level Trips (Ski Trip, Richmond, or Nashville), please fill out this survey.

Thank you all so much for your time! I hope to see you soon :)

od afternoon class,

One of your classmates created a GroupMe for our class. This is just a forum where you can talk about hw problems, etc. Just be sure to not discuss tests until after grades are posted. Joining is optional: https://app.groupme.com/join_group/70175934/kBxDFWqJ

I'm copying our new recitation leader, Tyler Knapp, on this email should you need to contact him.

The following announcement is regarding study groups for CH 101, MA 141/241/242, and PY 205/208. Keep on reading if you are interested in any of those! 

Ms. Kurtz

____________________________________________________________

ANNOUNCEMENT:

This Fall, Engineering Ambassadors are organizing study groups for students in CH 101, MA 141/241/242, and PY 205/208. This will be an excellent opportunity for you to work on homework, go over lecture notes, study for tests, and meet other STEM students. You do not have to be in engineering in order to participate! If you're interested in participating please complete the Google form below by Friday (8/27).

 

Why join a study group? Studies have shown that students absorb material a lot better through collaboration. As a part of a study group, you will:

Fill in any gaps in your understanding

Gain a new perspective on the material

Strengthen your understanding by teaching others

Reduce your potential to procrastinate

Break the monotony of studying alone



To join a study group, you must attend a virtual Study Group Meet-Up for the subject(s) of your choice led by the Engineering Ambassador team. You are only required to go to one session in order to participate in a group for that subject. 

 

For the first week of meet-ups, we will have 2 sessions per respective date. The Meet-Ups will be held as follows, all via Zoom: 

Calculus (MA 141, 241, and 242): 

Monday, 8/30: 6:00 - 6:45 PM and 7:15 - 8:00 PM

Physics (PY 205 and PY 208): 

Tuesday, 8/31:  6:00 - 6:45 PM and 7:15 - 8:00 PM

Chemistry (CH 101): 

Wednesday 9/01: 6:00 - 6:45 PM and 7:15 - 8:00 PM

 

For the second week of meet-ups, we will have 1 session per day.. The Meet-Ups will be held as follows, all via Zoom: 

 

Physics (PY 205 and PY 208): 

Tuesday, 9/07, 6:00-6:45 PM

Chemistry (CH 101): 

Wednesday 9/08, 6:00 - 6:45 PM

Calculus (MA 141, 241, and 242): 

Thursday, 9/09, 6:00 - 6:45 PM



During these Meet-ups, we will be creating the groups and going through some of the campus resources.

 

Please RSVP using the following links. You may RSVP for multiple subjects, but you must fill out the form in order to receive the Zoom link.

 

Link to RSVP for Chemistry

Link to RSVP for Calculus

Link to RSVP for Physics

 

The forms will close on Friday, August 27. The Zoom links will be sent out the morning of the Study Group session.

 

It is mandatory that you attend one of the three Meet-Ups (for a particular subject) if you wish to participate in one of the study groups at any point during this semester. If you are unable to make any of the Meet-ups, or have any questions, please email the Engineering Study Groups Committee (ncsu.esg@gmail.com) and we will be able to assist you.


--
Leslie Kurtz
Senior Lecturer
Transfer Officer
Director of Summer School
North Carolina State University 
Department of Mathematics
Office: SAS 3240
Email: lakurtz@ncsu.edu
Phone: 919.513.2111
Webpage: https://kurtz.wordpress.ncsu.edu

date:	Sep 16, 2021, 4:21 PM
subject:	URGENT - Complete I-9 Paperwork Immediately for Official/Scorekeeper Position
Sports Programs New Hire,

Our records indicate that you have not completed Section 1 online for your I-9 paperwork and have not completed Section 2 at the I-9 Center on campus. This step is required for you to continue working at Wellness and Recreation and attend trainings on Sunday for Official and/or Scorekeeper.

Please email me back once you completed Section 1! 

As long as you have completed Section 1, you will be able to attend Sunday's training. You then have 3 business days to complete Section 2 in person.

The following instructions were sent in your initial Onboarding email from Stephen Tucci.

Completing I-9 Sections 1 & 2
After selecting an orientation date, you will receive (please give it a few days if it does not come right away) an email (from perfectcompliance.com or DoNotReply, with the heading of “Your NC State University Employee I-9 Account Has Been Created”) providing you with information on completing Section 1 of your I-9, Employment Eligibility Verification Form, which we ask that you do remotely, at home. It is your responsibility to complete Section 1 on time. If you do not complete Section 1, you will not be able to complete Section 2 of your I-9, Employment Eligibility Verification Form. 

 

Note: Your Social Security number (SSN) will be required to complete Section 1. If you do not have one, you need to apply for one. If you DO need to apply for a Social Security number, you must check the Awaiting Issuance of SSN box in the “U.S. Social Security No”. field in Section 1.


After you have completed Section 1, Section 2 must be completed within three business days after Wellness and Recreation New Student Employee Orientation. An authorized representative of NC State University must complete Section 2 with your original I-9 Acceptable Documents in-person, so you will need to make arrangements to visit the I-9 Center. 

 

Review the government’s list of I-9 Acceptable Documents.

 

Bring original documents (no copies) from this list; be sure to bring in one selection from List A, OR a combination of one selection from List B and one selection from List C.

Section 2 Completion The I-9 Center, located in room 101 of the Administrative Services II (2711 Sullivan Drive), is open Monday – Friday from 9:00 am – 4:00 pm. Walk-in appointments are available. If you have questions, please email i9questions@ncsu.edu.  

 

The I-9 Center has made many modifications to their building and their service to best ensure the safety of customers and their staff.  For your safety and the safety of others, the following are required of all individuals visiting the I-9 Hub:

·   	You must wear a face mask during the appointment, 

·   	You must maintain a distance of least 6 feet from others, and

·   	You must enter and exit only through the specifically marked doors.

·   	Please review the following information about safety on the Protect the Pack website and in the How to Return to Campus Safely Guide.


Important information for F-1/J-1 international student employees: 

Under U.S. employment law, an employee's attendance of an employer's required orientation, onboarding and/or trainings is considered employment hours and must be paid. As such, time spent in Wellness and Recreation’s orientation, onboarding, and trainings (including those completed remotely by the employee such as an online training done at home) will be recorded and paid by NCSU in the week(s) in which they occur. As a reminder, F-1/J-1 international students are limited to 20/hours per week of on-campus employment when school is in session. Therefore, if you have other on-campus employment, you may need to reduce your hours at that job to ensure you do not exceed 20 hours/week total of on-campus employment when you attend Wellness and Recreation's required orientation, onboarding and/or trainings. If you have a 0.5 FTE graduate assistantship or are not able to reduce your current on-campus employment hours, you may need to attend the new employer's required events once Summer or Winter break has begun or during a week when there is a break in classes such as Fall Break, Thanksgiving Break, Spring Break, or Spring Holiday. If you have questions about this, please speak with an OIS advisor before attending these events.  


For questions related to Form I-9, E-Verify, and New Student Employee Orientation please contact Stephen Tucci at sltucci@ncsu.edu; for questions about your new position, please contact your direct supervisor. 


--
Ben Strunk
Assistant Director, Sports Programs
Wellness and Recreation
NC State University
Division of Academic and Student Affairs
P: 919.515.1862
wellrec.ncsu.edu

From: COGDEN@augusta.edu <COGDEN@augusta.edu>
Sent: Friday, April 26, 2024 2:28:37 PM
Cc: Burdette, Kaitlyn <KAIBURDETTE@augusta.edu>
Subject: Live Binder
 
I'm finding so many similar problems with LiveBinder I decided to just email everyone.  If you have finished it correctly, just ignore this email.  The comments I keep sharing:

Make it public.  I can't see it until you do.

Upload the link to the actual LiveBinder from your account.  I need to see your LiveBinder project, not just all the documents and assignments from this course.

Take all first person references out of your research.  There are no "I," "me," "my," etc. in professional research.  You use phrases such as "the authors share.....", or "according to (author) in (article) ........, or " research show that...."

Remove all class headings from all assignments.  This should not read like a compilation of class work.  In fact, your name is only on your LiveBinder.

You will not need an outline AND a table of contents.  They are the same, so pick one.

Avoid links inside LiveBinder.  Use as few as possible.  Each new tab should not be another link to open.  Think about your Week 8 presentation and how smoothly you will want to move from one document to the next.

Make sure all pictures and videos are right side up.  Some are posting sideways.

I've only had 2 (out of 20) that I graded.  All others needs at least some tweaking.  So let's just say you edit this weekend and I begin to grade Monday.  Review yours for all the notes above and resubmit when you've had a chance to clean it up.  Message or email me if you have additional questions.

Kaitlyn has agreed to provide assistance if needed.  You can email her at kaiburdette@augusta.edu.  If others who seem to know how to navigate LiveBinder also agree to support, I'll share their names with you so we don't kill Kaitlyn!!

Good morning, all!  I think I have this figured out.  A team from AU put the AU Online course syllabus and outlines together, so this is confusing at first.  Hang with me!

In Module 0 you find Welcome and Course Overview which houses Syllabus A, Syllabus B, and Course Due Dates.  Course Due Dates has accurate dates for generic assignments.  So IF we have an Hypothes.is assignment in Module 1, the due date is given.  If there is not an Hypothes.is assignment in Module 1, you ignore that due date.  Course Syllabus A is specific to our course and lists the assignments due in each module, but it does not give dates.  So you need to cross reference the assignments listed in Syllabus A with Course Due Dates to see when each task is due.

I'm sorry for the confusion.  Please let me know if you have additional questions. 

Cheri Ogden

We are requesting parents in our Pre-kindergarten classrooms to avoid sending any cashews and pistachios.  We do have a friend who is severely allergic to cashews and pistachios. Please make sure all food items for any classroom events are store bought to comply with our school policy and are allergen free.  There are no exceptions to this simply due to the safety of all the children in our school.

email_text:
From: Nanticoke Indians Info <info@nanticokeindians.org>
Date: Thu, Jan 25, 2024 at 7:29 PM
Subject: Unpaid NIA 2024 Dues
To: Nanticoke Indians Info <info@nanticokeindians.org>



Dear Member,  

                       

            This letter is a courteous reminder that as of January 15, 2024, we have not received your payment of membership dues for the current 2024 year. We certainly understand that oversights happen with all the other day to day priorities placed on us as individuals. As a valued member of the Nanticoke Indian Association, “NIA,” we are providing you this gentle reminder.

 

Through the Nanticoke Indian Association and its members and despite the coronavirus pandemic, we are continuing our work to improve our Tribal awareness, our Tribal community, education opportunities, job training, and employment opportunities along with providing other valuable resources that work to improve the quality of life for our members and the tribe.

 

The Nanticoke Indian Association Dues assist us in many ways including funding family-oriented activities, cultural sharing, and community events that will resume as soon as it is safe for our members, volunteers, and staff.  These events raise money to support our association, historic museum, student scholarships, and our neighboring tribal community. 

 

According to the following By-Laws adopted on June 7, 2005 and revised on August 5, 2014:

 

Annual Dues shall be assessed to each Regular and Associate Member in the amount of TEN DOLLARS ($10.00), due on January 1st of each year. 
Any member unable to pay his/her dues by January 15th of the current year shall receive a written notice that his/her Membership dues are past due.  
If dues are not paid by February 28th of the current year, the Member will be removed from the membership rolls.
Should you be dropped from the membership rolls because of non-payment of dues, reinstatement requires that you complete and submit all paperwork, genealogies, fees, etc. 
Current Reinstatement fee is $60.00 - this includes fees and dues.
If the applicant is below the age of 18 years, the reinstatement fee is $35.00 (fees and dues). 
 

We certainly would not want to lose you as a valued member due to a mere oversight on your behalf.  We would like you to know we truly appreciate you as a member and welcome your continued support in the upcoming year.  Also, please know that you can renew for multiple years if this is more convenient for you.

 

If you feel you have received this notice in error, please contact the NIA office immediately, so we can update our records. We apologize in advance for any errors and as always welcome your feedback!

 

Should you have any questions or concerns regarding membership, please contact the office which is open Monday through Friday from 10 a.m. to 3 p.m. or email info@nanticokeindians.org.

 

Sincerely,

                                                                                                                                               

Avery S. Johnson

 

Avery S. Johnson, Chief

ASJ/cjp

 

 

The Nanticoke Indian Association, Inc.

27073 John J. Williams Highway

Millsboro, DE 19966

Phone:  (302) 945-3400

Fax:  (302) 947-9411

Info@Nanticokeindians.org
